“The school culture starts with the basics around safety and civility because no one is going to go to college who has been shot dead on the streets of Boston or in their high school. So safety and civility is first, kind of a Maslow hierarchy of needs.”

“Behavioral and cultural standards have to be the foundation or a kid just won’t learn and teachers can’t teach,” he says. “We have to have the culture right before kids will learn. The culture here is driven largely by relationships and the structure around relationships. There is a code of conduct that, if applied uniformly and consistently, the culture will be impervious. Culture is key.”

“This is the safest place for them to be … Last Saturday there was a shooting in our neighborhood. Outside is not safe … Overall they feel safe and the main reason for that is because of the structures we put in place. We build for safety, for emotional safety. For 6 years, we’ve had single-sex advisories that are multiaged, and I think that has been really important for feeling safe here.”

“Students would describe [CPS 4] as physically safe, they would describe it as, compared to another school, whether that was their previous school, as a much better environment because they are freer to risk their ideas. The capacity for debate and intellectual development is better [at CPS 4].”
“Kids don’t care how much adults know until they know how much adults care.”

“I think the boys are doing so well because there is built in time for the boys to only be with boys and they can take a rest from hormone display behavior and they can learn to ask for help … When kids are living with that much, an immersion of violence, I think, to get their test scores up, you have to get some of their other problems off their minds.”
“A small school for urban kids is the first precondition to having an effective urban school. A small school allows community; it allows relationships.”
“We are building social capital in this community, and we’re doing it quite consciously. We’re trying to develop a diverse pipeline of leadership for Boston.”

“Our school, I think, is effective at being more than a school … if your high school is not going to back you up and carry you through, then who is going to? So, we have to rethink, what an urban school is. What is an urban high school? It’s a community center, it’s a family center.”

sec.p: CPS 1’s conceptual model emphasizes the creation and maintenance of a safe learning environment through civil engagement and an emphasis on citizenship. At CPS 1, a safe school environment is essential for students not only to focus on academics (like CPS 2 and CPS 4) but also to enable students to openly and civilly participate in their learning community as a future citizen in a democratic society. Like CPS 4, at CPS 3, safety is a primary focus of the organization as it is assumed the school is one of the safest places in its students’ lives. The school serves as an extended family center for each student to aid in the processing of the violence they experience as residents of the most violent neighborhoods in Boston. Only then can students access the expeditionary learning curriculum.

sec.title: Third dimension: Shared mission and vision by all faculty and staff
sec.p: The third and final common dimension identified by leadership pertains to the mission and vision of the school and the dedication of all members of the community to the school’s success. In all four schools, leadership underscored the importance of the school’s mission—and its pervasiveness throughout the school community—as a key element of the school’s success. Despite the differences among the schools’ missions, each school community has a distinctive organizational culture resulting from a clear emphasized mission and vision that combines elements to create an environment that engages students and teachers alike. Each leader described the mission of their schools as a central focus of theirs, were personally connected to the mission, and were passionate about it. They emphasized ownership of the organization’s mission and vision by all faculty and staff to enable the mission and vision to achieve fruition. Leadership describes being able to lead efficiently and effectively because the mission and vision of their schools are defined, purposeful, and shared. All four leaders have established the expectation that all members of the community are to be integral members of the community while embodying the mission and philosophy of the organization. Faculty and staff members, who do not engage in the community according to the mission or subscribe to cultural standards, do not remain employed at any of the charter public schools for very long. Although all four leaders emphasize a school community driven by a shared mission, each school’s mission is distinct. The strengths, experience, and priorities of each school’s leadership shapes the professional culture differently (Table 7).

caption.p: Leaders’ Concepts of Shared Mission and Vision of All Faculty and Staff at Four Charter Public Schools

tr.td: Leader statements
“We are a school that knows its mission and vision and the teachers are incredibly important in forming the details of what that looks like.”

“A relentless work ethic is the number one characteristic of the professional culture in the school. Nobody seems to be the weak link in the chain. Everybody seems to be here at 7 in the morning, everyone is here at 7 at night. Most people are here on Saturdays. People are on email in the evenings. The culture is a 60 hr a week, do-what-it-takes attitude with no questions asked. If you’re a teacher who is struggling, we’d like to help you and get you to stop struggling or send you off to another job.”

“The kids would cast [the mission] in terms of the school’s motto, which is ‘to learn, to lead, and to serve.’ They will speak about that. I think the mission is very alive. I think that the school is very mission driven.”

“Pay attention to all of it, all the rituals and daily routines. The symbols, the small pieces that add up to what your culture stands for. Pay attention to the really clear guideposts for all students. Be bold about the culture and use Japanese words and hold hands and shout and all that. The community must pay attention all the things that are different and will signify that this is a different place. Pay attention to all of those details. Start small and grow it.”

“CPS 1 has a mission to close the achievement gap … Our students still continue to struggle with aspects of behavior and academics. Until we get our students through those struggles, we can’t say that we are getting to young Black boys and Hispanic boys to enable them to be successful academically.”

“A good leader will then attract good teachers, teachers that will see that leader has the ability to inspire and build relationships, teachers interested in building a relationship in a small community. The kind of leader who is looking to lead a high school of 3,000 kids is not the kind of leader I want.”

“Our school, I think, is effective at being more than a school. Our school is more than a school. We are building social capital in this community, and we’re doing it quite consciously. We’re trying to develop a diverse pipeline of leadership for Boston … I think we’ve taken on more … But from our point of view, if we’re really going to get kids through college and beyond, then we think, I think, that’s what it takes … And if your high school is not going to back you up and carry you through then who is going to? So, we have to rethink, what an urban school is. What is an urban high school? It’s a community center, it’s a family center.”

“What is not in our mission is our college focus. If you asked our students right now what the mission of our school is, they would not say ‘to combine the best elements of East and West’ they would say ‘to get into college.’ So our mission statement now is sort of the way that we do it.”

“There really is a moral imperative that when you have a small school and you know all the kids and you know all the families and you are in some ways heartbroken by the disservice of the middle school education they have received.”

“Fewer than 10% are likely to graduate from a 4-year college without some sort of positive life-altering experience. The mission of CPS 2 is precisely to create that life-altering experience to ensure our students actually succeed in college.”

“We have a ritual for every person every year when you must figure out your intention for the year. We’re focused on intentionality. A student said the other day, ‘at this school everyone has a mission statement and the seniors’ mission statement is so much more interesting than mine. Mine is like, get through the 9th grade, theirs is like, change the world.’ We make a booklet where we publish everyone’s intentions … You know, when you are working with a kid, you can step back and say, ‘what is your intention for the year?’”

“I think the student culture right now is one that the students feel that they have one strong relationship with their teachers or the other adults in the school, it is very collegial in that sense. Everyone knows each other for better or for worse. There’s no hiding.”

“There is an acceptance of the violence, an acceptance of mediocrity for these students that we serve. People do not accept this level of violence or this low level of academic achievement in the suburbs. That really fuels an indignation and a moral imperative that gets you out of bed in the morning and forces you, really forces you, to do the hard work of closing that achievement gap … I think that runs in the veins of everyone that is committed to closing the achievement gap.”

“We expect every student who comes here, whether that student is at a second-grade reading level, or not, to graduate from here and attend a 4-year college or university. That is our clear, transparent message from day one when they, as 8th graders, take a look at our school from all the hard years here. To some kids, we say it will take 5 or 6 years to get there, but that’s reasonable. But if a kid is applying here and enrolling here, that is the expectation: no excuse, no fail. We know that there are things going on in their lives, we know that their friends are being shot, we know they have family health issues, we know they have friends in the neighborhood who think they are crazy for coming here. We set that aside and say no excuses, set that aside, this is what you’re doing. So everyone holds to that expectation and everyone holds to that standard …”

“The CPS 4 student culture has gone from an adult-controlled, adult-directed culture to one that encourages student ownership, student voice, and student initiative. That’s happened over time probably because our high school grew out of our middle school. It’s had to develop over time, but I think we grew it very intentionally as we tried to think of 9th and 10th differently than 11th and 12th. As a student goes farther in our high school, there is a little bit more responsibility.”

“The school culture is focused on going to college. It’s very easy to connect everything else with college. The school culture is made up of everyone’s values in the building but also the habits and culture of the families that are bringing these kids to school every day and who are present in their students’ lives when we are not there. The word college is the word that is held in common by everyone. We are all doing this because it is going to get your child into college.”
“Everyone at CPS 1 speaks a shared language.”
“We are a school that knows its mission and vision and the teachers are incredibly important in forming the details of what that looks like …”

sec.p: CPS 1’s conceptual model of a vision enforced by all adult community members emphasizes the combination of academic excellence and civic engagement by increasing the interdependence between academic standards and citizenship across the curriculum. Leadership did so by particularly emphasizing everyone in the community speaking a “shared language” emphasizing college for all students, the ultimate goal of an education at CPS 1.

According CPS 2 leadership, the shared school vision is the foundation to maintaining behavioral and cultural standards by all faculty and staff, which in turn contributes to the school’s safety and quality of the relationships between adults and students. CPS 2’s strong and consistent culture enables adults to hold students accountable for poor behavior or breaking rules without creating animosity or mistrust. Leadership emphasized this vision to implement the mission at CPS 2 by creating core values for the whole community centered on an urgent and tireless work ethic. All stakeholders, from teachers and tutors to students, are expected to embody a “relentless” work ethic. Those who are unable to achieve the community’s work ethic do not remain as community members for long.

CPS 3’s conceptual model of schoolwide buy-in emphasizes an urgency by all faculty and staff in the service to the students regarding issues of physical and emotional safety and academic development. Teachers are to embody the school’s motto, which is “to learn, to lead, and to serve,” by modeling service in support of students. For CPS 3 to be a safe environment that functions like a supportive family, all teachers are expected to engage in the policies and systems of support for the students. The explicit nature of CPS 3’s mission and vision attracts many of the faculty and staff with strong buy-in to the school making the policies and programs more effectively implemented. To have all community members embody the mission of CPS 4, leadership emphasized intense, detailed, and daily attention to the culture of the school. All faculty and staff must openly conduct the many rituals that are part of the culture to achieve a safe and supportive environment for the students.

sec.title: The Interdependence Between the Three Dimensions
sec.p: Each of the four leaders in this study specifically and pointedly emphasized three dimensions essential to their school’s success: the high expectation of college for all students, student safety, and a mission shared by the whole school community. That four school leaders with disparate experiences, backgrounds, and credentials independently integrated these values into their schools and achieved student results that outperform the sending district suggests that these characteristics are more than idiosyncratic preferences. Each leader had the leeway to create a unique organizational culture shaped by their understanding and interpretation of these three dimensions. They oversee a wide range of common programmatic characteristics in contexts of differing school missions, while managing to achieve positive outcomes among demographic groups most public schools poorly serve.

To say being the leader of an urban school is difficult certainly is an understatement. Though difficult, the findings of this study suggest that to be a leader of an urban public school that raises the outcomes of Black and Hispanic students from low-income families requires leadership that combines key characteristics or ingredients in just the right way. The three key dimensions in the conceptual models distilled from interviews with the leaders of these four urban charter high schools in Boston emphasize how interdependent (and interrelated) all aspects of the school are. For any one of the three dimensions to be effective, the leadership has to determine how to align each dimension in the context of the school’s mission and values. It seems each dimension must interact with the other models in a balanced and complementary way. For example, to help students meet high expectations, a school must emphasize emotional and physical safety for students at the school. For safety to be established and well maintained, all faculty and staff must embrace and enforce the school’s standards for behavior and academic rigor, the school’s mission, and values. This is no small task. The four leaders of this study seem able to align these dimensions in particular ways within each unique organizational culture. They are able to achieve effective interdependence of sophisticated parameters as the result of a strong conviction and belief in their school’s mission and vision. It seems that the parameters resulting from being charter public schools enable the four leaders in this study to accomplish this delicate balance.

sec.title: Discussion and Implications
sec.p: The achievement gap in the United States persists. The findings of this study help identify dimensions of site-based leadership that can interact to raise the academic achievement of low-income Black and Hispanic students while also acknowledging the difficulty of implementing the right combination of school characteristics to form an effective conceptual model. In Massachusetts, charter public school legislation was created with the intention of empowering school-site leadership to create school environments that would be transformative for all students regardless of race or socioeconomic background. The promise of the charter public school model offers flexibility and autonomy for leaders to enable them to experiment and be innovative. Although Massachusetts charter public schools, like charters nationwide, have had mixed success, this study explored the views of leaders of four successful charter public schools with Black and Hispanic populations and from low-income families in an effort to capture the elements of each conceptual model.

The findings of this study support Rutter et al.’s (1979) findings that the cumulative effect of the specific characteristics of effective schools is considerably greater than the effect of any individual factors on their own. Though all four schools in this study have very similar characteristics, the leadership and the schools are very different. Neither does implementing a list of characteristics make an effective school nor can a blueprint useful for running one school be applied to another hoping for similar positive results. Replicating a laundry list of programmatic characteristics may only lead to limited success without strong underlying values and site-based leadership passionately developing and implementing those characteristics. The characteristics that leaders in this study chose are not “out of the box” or “off the shelf.” Making classes small, extending the school day, or requiring uniforms may not improve student outcomes unless directly connected to a strong mission and vision. The choice of a simple characteristic, like the wearing of school uniforms, should stem from the implementation of leadership’s conceptual model. Within all four schools, leaders placed an emphasis on school safety; for example, uniforms were chosen to contribute to maintaining a safe school environment. However, no leader would point to uniforms as being the primary cause for student success. All four leaders interviewed in this study acknowledge the centrality of these three key dimensions while emphasizing how they implement them differently, depending on their school mission, school values, and the leader’s particular vision and personality. As a result, the organizational culture at each school significantly varies. It is the cumulative effect of these dimensions that makes each school effective and allows each to seemingly overcome the social, psychological, and economic challenges that face urban students and are associated with the achievement gap.

The creation of charter public schools was an attempt to empower individual school leaders, free from district constraints, while holding them strictly accountable for student outcomes. They were created from a belief that large-scale reform would not occur from within the school systems as they currently function. The findings of this study suggest that the four site-based leaders were able to find productive combinations of characteristics within the autonomy that their charter public school legislation allowed. Most importantly, the leaders of the four schools in this study seem to be moving in a direction that could effectively mitigate race-related obstacles to learning. As Black students make up the largest demographic in all four schools in this study, the academic achievement of the four schools suggests the leadership addressed what Tatum (1997), Ogbu (2003), and Ferguson (2008) identify as one of the most daunting challenges to the achievement gap: the racial identity and motivation of minorities. It is noteworthy that all of the charter public school founders and all four leaders interviewed for this study were White or Asian and the majority of the faculty and staff of each charter public school also did not reflect the racial or ethnic background of the students. This suggests that leadership and the resulting school organizational culture and policies may be more important than the demographics of those leading and implementing each program.

Schools effective at raising the achievement of low-income students often have similar characteristics. This study supports that finding and suggests how the charter model holds promise by offering leadership the flexibility to create different organizational cultures that combine the key dimensions of effective schools especially those with high-poverty, high-minority students. All four charter high schools in this study had dedicated, invested, and passionate leaders who not only believed in but also embodied the values and vision of their school. Each school leader determined the values, procedures, and structures of the organization. The individual characteristics of each school in this study are similar, and the leaders acknowledged the centrality of three key dimensions. However, the leaders diverged in how they understood, implemented, and aligned elements of these dimensions with the organizational cultures and values of each school.

One of the main elements of charter school legislation in Massachusetts was that charter public schools were created to be free from bureaucratic requirements. However, charter public schools have more layers of accountability than any other public school. Specifically, the charter public schools in this study are held accountable to the standards of all public schools: federal adequate yearly progress (AYP) goals as articulated by No Child Left Behind, federal civil rights, and special education requirements and optional accreditation by the New England Association of Schools and Colleges (CPS 1 is accredited, the only charter in the study). In addition, to these universal public school accountability requirements, charter public schools are subject to evaluation by the Massachusetts Department of Education Charter School Office for renewal every 5 years. Thus, charter public schools are required to succeed or face the consequence of closure. No other public school faces such high and rigorous standards.

Although charter public schools are subject to the most regulations in Massachusetts, they have more autonomy than any other public school in the state to choose their curriculum, program, schedule, calendar, and staff. Each charter leader in this study specifically cited qualities such as flexibility and autonomy to hire and fire staff, set budget priorities, set academic goals, and create school culture. These characteristics are driven by the value-based decisions that leaders are free to make in a school environment of paired autonomy and accountability. It seems that a significant amount (if not most) of what leadership was able to accomplish in the running of their schools would not be possible without their charter status. For example, each leader has the ability to hire and fire faculty and staff (all employees in the charters in this study sign 1-year contracts). Leaders in this study emphasized attracting individuals who desire to be part of the mission-driven professional community and strenuous working conditions that each school offers. This combination of accountability and autonomy required the leadership of the schools in this study to remain focused on student achievement while possessing the authority to lead their schools as they thought best. Focusing on results within a strict time frame fosters urgency to attain the goal of raising student performance. All the leaders in this study were urgent in their quest to raise the achievement of their students, and the decisions they made were in the context of high-stakes accountability and autonomy, not in spite of it.

Nevertheless, it must be emphasized that all fours schools struggled at times to post student outcomes that surpassed the district (since completion of this study, some continue to do so on some indices). Certain years saw low scores on MCAS and low graduation rates. Tracking student outcomes over a longer period of time is an area that deserves further study. Also, the history of the schools in this study illustrates that poor leadership can quickly have deleterious effects to the outcomes of a school. This was the case with CPS 1, which faced closure by the State Board of Education, due to teacher attrition, a dip in scores, and budgetary issues. New leadership stepped in and righted the ship, narrowly avoiding closure.

Though there is evidence of narrowing the gap on state tests, the leaders of all four schools modestly and sincerely stated that any claim of narrowing the achievement gap by them or their school would be premature. Leaders were quick to point out that they had not achieved success all the time on all indices. However, they all achieved success much of the time (and since completion of this study, continue to do so). Leaders all emphasized the presence of an achievement gap and believe their charge is to significantly raise student performance to narrow the gap and that the gap can be narrowed by decisions made at the school level to mitigate factors beyond their control outside of school. All leaders acknowledge success in outperforming their sending district and state averages for their school’s demographics according to some indices, but all leaders emphasize that their organizations will not be successful in closing the achievement gap until their schools have demonstrated consistent success in matriculating their graduates to and graduating from college. This long-term view and value may be a contributing factor to the professional culture of the school, further motivating faculty and staff to diligently work with students on the short-term goals to achieve the school’s long-term goals.

The overarching finding of this study is that four charter public schools are successful because of their leadership. The leadership of each school demonstrated success to some extent raising student achievement of students who arrive behind academically. Thus, the findings of this study further support the claim that, though demography may be a strong predictor of student outcomes, demography is not destiny—school-based leadership can catch students up academically interdependent of their race or socioeconomic status.

Despite the findings of this study, the finding of the Coleman report 40 years ago cannot be dismissed. Policy makers, educators, and school leaders must understand the influence of demography on the achievement of low-income and minority students to raise the outcomes of those students. The Coleman Report’s findings that families have a more significant influence than school quality on achievement is too easily misinterpreted as the notion that schools do not make a difference in the lives of young people. Schools have the most influence on a student’s academic development than anything outside the home. However, the strongest predictor of which children will do better in math and which will do worse is not what school they attend but their family income. As most Black and Hispanic and low-income citizens live in the same neighborhoods and most school enrollment is determined by area of residence, Black and Hispanic students attend schools with student populations that predictors say will do poorly. This begs the question that is the foundation of this study. If student outcomes can be predicted based on race and family, what are leaders of schools whose student demographics will predict poor performance doing differently to positively affect their academic outcomes? A final reflection of how well public school administrators serve their low-income Black and Hispanic students who arrive at high school academically behind their White, Asian, and non-low-income peers is the number of students who graduate from college. At worst, it seems that most urban schools in the United States, and the administrators who make the day-to-day decisions in these urban schools, continue to implement the same program hoping for different results; at best, the deliberate actions of urban public school leaders consistently fail despite sincere effort. The outcome, however, remains unacceptably the same.

The leaders of the four charter public schools in this study seem to recognize that their school has limited impact on external factors, that low-income, Black, and Hispanic students will most likely come to school with academic deficits, and that their schools can accelerate the rate at which their students progress, enabling those who enter school behind to catch up to their peers. Thus, the Coleman report’s conclusions are not at all counterintuitive; indeed, it makes perfect sense that the economic, educational, and cultural characteristics of families have powerful effects on learning. The leaders studied here seem to understand that socioeconomic differences are not determinative but are evidence of inequity of school readiness. They seem to sincerely believe that if their students are willing to work, then they can go to and graduate from college. This readiness is not a fact of nature but is mostly because of differences in life experience. Though leaders cannot change past-life experience, they can affect current and future school experience. Leaders of schools with low-income Black and Hispanic populations must be sure that their leadership takes into account the nuances of the Coleman report and the research on the Black–White test score gap in the running of their schools (see discussions in Epps, 1992; Ferguson, 2006; Rothstein, 2004; Tough, 2006). When orchestrating the multidimensional elements of their schools, the leaders of the schools in this study seem to capture the correct balance to mitigate the complex deleterious factors of race and income.

Persistence of an academic achievement gap in 2010 across all public schools in the United States has to be connected, at some level, to the leadership at the school level. Leaders are in a position to change their school environments and transform conditions that have contributed to the persistent achievement gap, particularly along dimensions such as academic expectations and whether the learning environment is safe, orderly, and aligned with school mission and values. Whether the academic deficiencies of today’s Black and Hispanic low-income students are the result of underdeveloped cognitive skills, inadequate motivation, conflicting cultural styles and values, or stressful community and family environments, school-site leadership can prudently take action to offset these factors. Leaders hold within their grasp the potential to shape the organizational cultures of their schools in ways that can foster learning and will lead to better academic performance, improve self-images, and build stronger motivation for academic achievement.

Unfortunately, I believe, if present parameters continue to exist for leadership in public schools, any future dramatic education reform in urban public high schools that serve low-income Black and Hispanic teens will only result from the actions of exceptional, dedicated, and disciplined individuals willing to remain committed to the schools they work in for a long period of time. Such leaders are not common, and worse, I fear, the conditions to attract such leaders to urban public education are not common enough, either, making any large-scale reform unlikely. For additional public school leaders to achieve what the leaders in this study achieved, they must be granted more autonomy balanced with fair accountability and increased resources. To be flexible in the leadership of their school environment, principals must have the power to hire and fire their employees, set cultural standards and consequences, set curriculum goals, and drive the quality of teaching and learning in the classroom. Such steps suggest addressing the status of tenure in all public schools, something nowhere being seriously considered in present education reform.

The findings of this study, and my own experience as a 17-year urban public school teacher and leader, corroborate the work of Tough (2006), who asserts that to raise the outcomes of low-income Black and Hispanic students, school leaders and their faculty and staff must invariably use methods that are radically different and set higher, more rigorous expectations than those employed in most traditional district public schools. However, conditions required to implement such strategies may be too far from traditional schooling or contrary to union collective bargaining agreements (such as lengthening the school day, week, and year) and, therefore, difficult to implement by a leader devoid of local autonomy.

The autonomy afforded to and accountability applied to the site-based charter public school leaders in this study warrant the consideration of policy makers, district officials, and elected officials to enable school leaders to develop their schools according to their beliefs, vision, training, and expertise. The rules governing charter public schools vary as much state-to-state as success varies from charter school–to–charter school. This study makes no assertion as to which rules governing charter schools are most effective, although, arguably, the granting of significant autonomy for these leaders seemed to be an aspect of their ability to accelerate student achievement. The number of charter public schools in the nation constitutes less than 5% of all public schools, and the number of new charters opening annually is decreasing. This is most likely the result of opposition to charters and a reluctance to raise cap numbers, as has been the case in Massachusetts (though it was recently raised in response to incentives put forth by the Obama administration). Therefore, I would recommend granting more leaders site-based autonomy (like that found in charter public schools), not necessarily opening more charter public schools.

In conclusion, the data in Boston indicate charter public high schools are narrowing the achievement gap (albeit, some more so than others and some more consistently than others). These four charter public schools are not only outperforming their sending district but also approaching, meeting, and in many cases surpassing the state average for all races and family income levels. This success is a result of high-stakes site-based accountability, not in spite of it. The high-stakes accountability and the accompanying autonomy that the charter school model offers are worth consideration by leaders at all public schools.

Our nation remains at risk as long as the achievement gap persists, signifying a public school system inconsistently meeting the needs of the citizens it is intended to develop. To raise student performance and narrow the achievement gap, we must attract, retain, and motivate leaders who will improve the teaching and learning in our nation’s public schools. They must be afforded the responsibility to construct conceptual models in the running of their school as the leaders of this study were permitted to do. As an administrator dedicated to the success of our nation’s urban high-poverty, high-minority public schools, I am committing my career to serving in urban public high schools—so long as there is a public school district to work in that will grant me site-based autonomy.

High-poverty district or school: A district or school with more than 50% of the student population from families at or below the poverty level. The poverty level in the United States for a single family with one child is US$13,000 and for a two-parent family with one child is US$15,200. As of 2004 in the United States, approximately 12% of the nation lived at or below the poverty level (National Poverty Center, 2004). High-minority: A district or school with more than 50% of the student population from minority families. Minority families are families consisting of individuals of Black and Latino or Hispanic racial backgrounds. (Though a minority, Asian students are not included as they consistently score in the top percentile of academic achievement in the United States.)

On the SAT, a gap exists according to race, too. However, this was not a focus of this study. On the SAT, Black and Hispanic students have performed, on average during the last decade, consistently lower than White and Asian students. This is notable because the SAT is not a representative sample of all high school students like the NAEP. As it is the test used by most colleges and universities as part of their admissions process, students who take the SAT self-select, having already achieved academic outcomes that would merit their admission to college. That is to say, a gap exists even when the scores of Black and Hispanic students who perform strongly in high school and plan to go to college are compared with the scores of college-bound Whites and Asian peers on a national scale.

bio.p: Paul Sitton Hays, EdD, principal, City on a Hill Charter Public School, Boston, Massachusetts, is a certified science teacher with 18 years of experience in urban public education.
